Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF: Quantifying the effects of flow transience on sediment transport
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Colin Phillips has been awarded an NSF Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a research and educational outreach plan at the University of Minnesota. He will investigate the process of gravel transport in response to transient and intermittent flooding. Gravel rivers represent the rate limiting step in the incision of mountains and also provide critical habitat and breeding grounds to numerous aquatic species. These experiments will form the basis for understanding how potential changes in climate and land use will affect gravel streams. In addition these experiments will provide a quantitative framework for stream managers regulating flow releases below dams and stream restoration projects. The results from these experiments will be turned into interactive online tools for stream restoration practitioners. Furthermore, the knowledge gained from this project will be transferred to young scientists through classes and experiments during the National Center for Earth Surface Dynamics 2 (NCED2) Summer Institute, and to future young scientists by collaborating with NCED2 REU students.

A large majority of our understanding of gravel river dynamics comes from flume experiments under constant or slowly varying floods. Many of the theories developed under steady flow provide reasonable predictions of the dynamics of gravel rivers when averaged over numerous floods, however due to the stochastic nature of sediment transport it remains unclear whether these predictions break down due to flow unsteadiness or granular phenomena. Through the use of laboratory experiments he will test the relative importance of flood shape and sequence to determine how an unsteady flow drives sediment transport. This project will compare the dynamics of gravel transport at the particle level through the tracking of several populations of marked particles under a variety of single and sequences of flows of varying magnitude and duration, but equivalent impulse (time-integrated momentum above the threshold of particle motion).

POR.DRECONTENT:
When enough rain falls within a mountain range its rivers flood and begin to move bits of the landscape downstream. A flooding river transports numerous types of material, some of it is dissolved in the water as solutes, other fine particles might flow downstream suspended rarely touching the bed, while a smaller amount of material moves in close contact with the bed through rolling, sliding and hopping. By mass, most of the material leaving a mountain range in a river consists of fine particles (clay, mud, silt, and sand) suspended in the water column, but the coarser material (pebbles, gravel, cobbles, and boulders) plays an important role in regulating long-term erosion and providing aquatic habitat. The coarse sediment that travels in close contact with the bed is called bed load transport and can act as a shield covering bedrock from impacts or it can act as the tools of erosion through collisions with exposed rock slowly incising the landscape. At much shorter timescales, the coarse material that moves during bed load transport also represents important habitat for aquatic insects and fish and represents the breeding grounds for ocean dwelling fish like Salmon. Due in part to the difficulty in obtaining accurate measurements of the processes occurring during a flood much of our understanding of bed load transport is derived from small-scale laboratory experiments. One of the barriers in transferring our knowledge of laboratory experiments to the natural environment is that most experiments are done under conditions of steady unchanging flow. In a natural river, the flow of water is almost always unsteady as the amount of water flowing increases and decreases during the rising and falling limbs of a flood. Results from natural rivers have shown that these unsteady effects may be important to understanding bed load transport and river dynamics.

A goal of this project was to explore these transient flow effects (unsteady and intermittent) on bed load transport as a way to begin extending the rich library of laboratory knowledge to natural rivers. In particular, laboratory experiments were performed to compare and contrast single and sequences of steady and unsteady floods of different shapes, peak magnitudes, and durations. Unlike previous studies, which mainly document before and after effects of transient flow on the sediment bed texture, this study developed a new metric (flood impulse) allowing steady and unsteady floods to be compared in a quantitative matter. The impulse parameter represents the total amount of momentum greater than the force needed to transport sediment within the flood. This impulse parameter allowed us to explore separately how the magnitude, duration, and shape of a flow might lead to different outcomes.

A primary result of this research is that the total amount of sediment moved by the experimental floods is proportional to the applied impulse parameter. This indicates that to predict the total amount of sediment moved we need only account for the total amount of flood impulse, and that flood shape, magnitude, and duration do not represent first-order controls on sediment dynamics. This result is contrary to past experiments and observations from natural rivers. In order to understand this discrepancy, we performed several additional experiments with different types of sediment beds to understand how different mixtures of sediment particle sizes might account for the variability observed in previous studies. Preliminary results from experiments with a bimodal sediment mixture indicate substantial deviations from the unimodal sediment mixture. This suggests that a complex sediment bed mixture is required to observe substantial effects due to transient flows. The results from these experiments are being transitioned into several computer tools to aid in the analysis and design of stream restoration projects.

To understand how flow variability and transience might affect natural rivers we analyzed channel geometry, which integrates over numerous flooding events, and stream-flow records from 186 coarse-grained rivers across the United States. We found that these river channels adjust their geometry such that floods slightly exceed the stress required to transport bed sediment – regardless of widely varying climatic, tectonic, lithologic and hydrologic controls. These findings indicate that at longer timescales flow transience plays a minor role in shaping the channel and suggests that to understand sediment fluxes we need only compute the flow impulse.

In addition to the experimental and hydrograph analysis, this fellowship provided substantial training for Dr. Phillips in experimental methods and techniques during his tenure at St. Anthony Falls Laboratory at the University of Minnesota. This fellowship allowed Dr. Phillips to mentor and work closely with several undergraduate students on these experiments and experiments of their own design. The results of this research have been presented at regional, national, and international scientific conferences, university departmental seminars, a short course for university students, and regional conferences for river restoration practitioners.
